name: HIP 71135
scenarioDescription:
The HIP 71135 Exoplanetary System

HIP 71135 is a star with 0.66 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.76 times its radius. It is located 105.54 light years away from the solar system.

HIP 71135 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.

HIP 71135 b

HIP 71135 b was discovered by the Las Campanas Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2019-04. Its semi-major axis is 0.34 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 87.19 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HIP 71135.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.21, which means that when HIP 71135 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.26 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.41. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HIP 71135 b is 18.80 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HIP 71135 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HIP 71135, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by Las Campanas Observatory.
